page.title: 01MILLAND VALLEY & ITS HANGERS
page.content: To the north of this rural area is a line of wooded hangers, mostly sweet chestnut regularly coppiced by manual craftsmen. To the south-east is a striking hill-line, bracken-clad and open: an excellent vantage point for viewing the broad valley of the area. The valley is a mixture of woodland (oak, chestnut etc. with pockets of softwood) and farmland (dairy, beef, sheep and arable). The centres of population are the small villages of Milland to the west and Redford to the south. Many attractive stone cottages, farms and hamlets are scattered here and there is a thriving village school. The valley was once very damp; it has been drained for agriculture in the last century or so but several streams and substantial ponds remain a feature. Local woodlands and agriculture employ some
